message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Experimental study of inequality and unpredictability in an artificial cultural market
Paper Abstract: Hit songs, books, and movies are many times more successful than average, suggesting that "the best" alternatives are qualitatively different from "the rest"; yet experts routinely fail to predict which products will succeed. We investigated this paradox experimentally, by creating an artificial "music market" in which 14,341 participants downloaded previously unknown songs either with or without knowledge of previous participants' choices. Increasing the strength of social influence increased both inequality and unpredictability of success. Success was also only partly determined by quality: The best songs rarely did poorly, and the worst rarely did well, but any other result was possible.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about hit songs:

## Definition

A hit song, also known as a hit record, hit single, or simply hit, is a recorded song or instrumental that becomes broadly popular or well-known.

## Chart Performance Standards

Although hit song means any widely played or big-selling song, the specific term hit record usually refers to a single that has appeared in an official music chart through repeated radio airplay audience impressions or significant streaming data and commercial sales.(no content)In the United States and the United Kingdom, a single is usually considered a hit when it reaches the top 40 of the Billboard Hot 100 or the top 75 of the UK Singles Chart.

## Classification

A hit single is variously called a number one hit, a top 5 hit, a top 10 hit, a top 20 hit, or a top 40 hit, depending on its peak position.

The search results also show examples of notable hit songs and chart records, including information about various artists and their successful releases across different eras of music.

Links: [{"title":"List of largest recorded music markets - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_largest_recorded_music_markets"},{"title":"Music industry - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Music_industry"},{"title":"Music Media-Mix Market - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Music_Media-Mix_Market"},{"title":"Night Market Life - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Night_Market_Life"},{"title":"This Little Piggy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/This_Little_Piggy"},{"title":"To market, to market - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/To_market,_to_market"},{"title":"List of music released by Romanian artists that has charted in major music markets - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_music_released_by_Romanian_artists_that_has_charted_in_major_music_markets"},{"title":"List of music released by Moldovan artists that has charted in major music markets - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_music_released_by_Moldovan_artists_that_has_charted_in_major_music_markets"},{"title":"Universal Music Publishing Group - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universal_Music_Publishing_Group"},{"title":"Streetlight Records - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Streetlight_Records"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about the music market:

## Global Music Markets

The world's largest recorded music markets are listed annually by the International Federation of the Phonographic Industry (IFPI), and the ranking is based on the retail value (rather than units) each market generates per year.

The United States has remained the biggest market for recorded music in IFPI history, except in 2010 when Japan topped the list. Japan has always stayed within the top two, while the United Kingdom, France, Germany, and Canada have consistently appeared among the top ten music markets throughout IFPI history.

## Industry Structure

In the 2000s, a majority of the music market is controlled by three major corporate labels: the French-owned Universal Music Group, the Japanese-owned Sony Music Entertainment, and the American-owned Warner Music Group. The largest portion of the live music market for concerts and tours is controlled by Live Nation, the largest promoter and music venue owner.

## Recent Development

Universal Music Publishing Group (UMPG) is a global music publishing company and is part of the Universal Music Group and has been ranked the #1 music publisher in market share by Billboard for multiple consecutive quarters.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Social influence"

Links: [{"title":"Social influence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_influence"},{"title":"Normative social influence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Normative_social_influence"},{"title":"Social influence bias - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_influence_bias"},{"title":"Social proof - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_proof"},{"title":"Social influences on fitness behavior - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_influences_on_fitness_behavior"},{"title":"Interpersonal influence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interpersonal_influence"},{"title":"Social contagion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_contagion"},{"title":"Social marketing intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_marketing_intelligence"},{"title":"Influence of mass media - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Influence_of_mass_media"},{"title":"Media and teen relationships - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Media_and_teen_relationships"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about social influence:

## Definition

Social influence is a broad term that relates to many different phenomena.

## Key Types of Social Influence

**Informational and Normative Influence**

Psychologists Morton Deutsch and Harold Gerard described two psychological needs that lead humans to conform to the expectations of others: our need to be right (informational social influence) and our need to be liked (normative social influence).(no content)Informational influence (or social proof) is an influence to accept information from another as evidence about reality.(no content)Informational influence comes into play when people are uncertain, either from stimuli being intrinsically ambiguous or because of social disagreement.(no content)Normative influence is an influence to conform to the positive expectations of others.

**Conformity**

Conformity is a type of social influence involving a change in behavior, belief, or thinking to align with those of others or with normative standards, and it is the most common and pervasive form of social influence.

**Other Forms**

A self-fulfilling prophecy is a prediction that directly or indirectly causes itself to become true due to positive feedback between belief and behavior.(no content)Social contagion involves the spontaneous spread of behaviors or emotions through a group, population or social network, consisting of two categories: behavioral contagion and emotional contagion.

## Research Foundations

Solomon Asch conducted classic conformity experiments in 1955 in which he asked participants to judge the similarity of lines and found that participants conformed over 36% of the time when confederates gave blatantly false answers.

Based on the search results, here's information about unpredictability:

## Conceptual Understanding

Predictability is the degree to which a correct prediction or forecast of a system's state can be made, either qualitatively or quantitatively, and unpredictability is the opposite—when such predictions cannot be reliably made.

The difference between predictable variation and unpredictable variation is one of the fundamental issues in the philosophy of probability, and different probability interpretations treat predictable and unpredictable variation differently.

## Sources of Unpredictability

Limitations on predictability could be caused by factors such as a lack of information or excessive complexity. In physics, Werner Heisenberg's indeterminacy principle puts limits on the accuracy with which such quantities can be known, so such perfect predictability is also theoretically impossible.

## Applications and Examples

In economics, the concept acknowledges some fundamental degree of ignorance, a limit to knowledge, and an essential unpredictability of future events. Additionally, a black swan event, as defined by Nassim Nicholas Taleb, is an important and inherently unpredictable event that, once occurred, is interpreted with the benefit of hindsight.

In computational systems, pseudorandom numbers are used, which ideally have the unpredictability of a truly random sequence, despite being generated by a deterministic process.

I've completed a web search for "Inequality economics." Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Scope

Economic inequality is an umbrella term for three concepts: income inequality, how the total sum of money paid to people is distributed among them; wealth inequality, how the total sum of wealth owned by people is distributed among the owners; and consumption inequality, how the total sum of money spent by people is distributed among the spenders.

## Measurement

The Gini coefficient (also known as the Gini index or Gini ratio), is a measure of statistical dispersion intended to represent the income inequality, wealth inequality, or consumption inequality within a nation or a social group.

## Global Trends

Historically, there has been a long-run trend towards greater economic inequality over time, with exceptions during the two World Wars and amid the creation of modern welfare states after World War II. However, while globalization has reduced the inequality between nations, it has increased the inequality within most nations, and inequality within most nations has risen significantly in the last 30 years, particularly among advanced countries.

## Economic and Social Effects

Research suggests that greater inequality hinders economic growth and macroeconomic stability, and that inequality of land and human capital reduce growth more than inequality of income. Additionally, effects of income inequality, researchers have found, include higher rates of health and social problems, and lower rates of social goods, a lower population-wide satisfaction and happiness and even a lower level of economic growth when human capital is neglected for high-end consumption.

## Policy Implications

Inequality is at the center stage of economic policy debate across the globe, as government tax and spending policies have significant effects on income distribution, with taxes and transfers decreasing income inequality by one-third in advanced economies.

Based on the search results, here's information about "cultural markets":

## Related Marketing Concepts

Multicultural marketing, also known as ethnic marketing, is a strategic approach in marketing aimed at specific ethnic audiences distinct from the majority culture within a country. This practice leverages the unique cultural attributes of ethnic groups—including language, traditions, celebrations, and religious practices—to effectively communicate with these audiences.

Cultural segmentation is used to classify markets according to their cultural origin, as culture is a major dimension of consumer behaviour.

## Cultural Goods and Industries

The term can also refer to markets in cultural industries. The major cultural industries include the book industry, the music industry and the film industry, where a major part of sales are concentrated in a very small number of bestsellers, blockbusters or hit singles, operating as a winner-take-all market.

## Geographic Examples

Some physical cultural markets, like Ichhra Bazaar in Lahore, are known for their traditional and cultural dresses and other handicrafts, while Market East is one of seven designated cultural districts in Indianapolis, Indiana.

Based on the search results, here's information about "cultural markets":

## Related Marketing Concepts

Multicultural marketing, also known as ethnic marketing, is a strategic approach in marketing aimed at specific ethnic audiences distinct from the majority culture within a country. This practice leverages the unique cultural attributes of ethnic groups—including language, traditions, celebrations, and religious practices—to effectively communicate with these audiences.

Cultural segmentation is used to classify markets according to their cultural origin, as culture is a major dimension of consumer behaviour.

## Cultural Goods and Industries

The term can also refer to markets in cultural industries. The major cultural industries include the book industry, the music industry and the film industry, where a major part of sales are concentrated in a very small number of bestsellers, blockbusters or hit singles, operating as a winner-take-all market.

## Geographic Examples

Some physical cultural markets, like Ichhra Bazaar in Lahore, are known for their traditional and cultural dresses and other handicrafts, while Market East is one of seven designated cultural districts in Indianapolis, Indiana.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Product quality"

Links: [{"title":"Quality (business) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quality_(business)"},{"title":"Act on Securing Quality, Efficacy and Safety of Products Including Pharmaceuticals and Medical Devices - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Act_on_Securing_Quality,_Efficacy_and_Safety_of_Products_Including_Pharmaceuticals_and_Medical_Devices"},{"title":"Made in Ukraine - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Made_in_Ukraine"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about product quality:

## Definition and Meaning

In business, engineering, and manufacturing, quality – or high quality – has a pragmatic interpretation as the non-inferiority or superiority of something (goods or services); it is also defined as being suitable for the intended purpose (fitness for purpose) while satisfying customer expectations.

## Subjectivity of Quality

Quality is a perceptual, conditional, and somewhat subjective attribute and may be understood differently by different people. For example, consumers may focus on the specification quality of a product/service, or how it compares to competitors in the marketplace, while producers might measure the conformance quality, or degree to which the product/service was produced correctly.

## Quality Management

Quality planning is implemented as a means of "developing the products, systems, and processes needed to meet or exceed customer expectations." Quality assurance is implemented as a means of providing enough confidence that business requirements and goals for a product and/or service will be fulfilled.

## Business Importance

Customers recognize that quality is an important attribute in products and services, and suppliers recognize that quality can be an important differentiator between their own offerings and those of competitors.

Doyne Farmer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J._Doyne_Farmer"},{"title":"Logistic regression - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logistic_regression"},{"title":"COVID-19 recession - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_recession"},{"title":"Nouriel Roubini - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nouriel_Roubini"},{"title":"English historical school of economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/English_historical_school_of_economics"},{"title":"Identity economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Identity_economics"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of prediction economics:

## Economic Forecasting

Economic forecasting is the process of making predictions about the economy.(no content)Forecasts can be made at a high level of aggregation—for example, for GDP, inflation, unemployment, or the fiscal deficit.

Economists use statistical analysis of historical data to determine the apparent relationships between particular independent variables and their relationship to the dependent variable under study. These relationships can then be applied to forecast future economic scenarios.

## Prediction Markets

Another important aspect of prediction economics involves prediction markets, also known as betting markets, information markets, decision markets, idea futures, gambling, or event derivatives, are open markets that enable the prediction of specific outcomes using financial incentives (gambling on real world events).(no content)Based mostly on an idea in 1945 by Austrian economist Friedrich Hayek, prediction markets are "mechanisms for collecting vast amounts of information held by individuals and synthesizing it into a useful data point".

## Demand Forecasting

Demand forecasting involves the prediction of the quantity of goods and services that will be demanded by consumers or business customers at a future point in time.(no content)The methods of demand forecasting entail using predictive analytics to estimate customer demand in consideration of key economic conditions.

Links: [{"title":"Design of experiments - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Design_of_experiments"},{"title":"Experiment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Experiment"},{"title":"Experimental psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Experimental_psychology"},{"title":"Scientific method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scientific_method"},{"title":"List of psychological research methods - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_psychological_research_methods"},{"title":"Exploratory research - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exploratory_research"},{"title":"Empirical research - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Empirical_research"},{"title":"Methodology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Methodology"},{"title":"Research design - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Research_design"},{"title":"Experimental political science - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Experimental_political_science"}]

I've completed a web search on "Experiment research methodology." Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Purpose

In the scientific method, an experiment is an empirical procedure that arbitrates competing models or hypotheses.(no content)Researchers also use experimentation to test existing theories or new hypotheses to support or disprove them.

## Core Components

An experimental design is the laying out of a detailed experimental plan in advance of doing the experiment.(no content)In an experimental design, the researcher actively tries to change the situation, circumstances, or experience of participants (manipulation), which may lead to a change in behavior or outcomes for the participants of the study. The researcher randomly assigns participants to different conditions, measures the variables of interest, and tries to control for confounding variables.

## Key Principles

Comparisons between treatments are much more valuable and are usually preferable, and often compared against a scientific control or traditional treatment that acts as baseline.(no content)Clear and complete documentation of the experimental methodology is also important in order to support replication of results.

## Research Approaches

The dominant methodology in the natural sciences is called the scientific method. It includes steps like observation and the formulation of a hypothesis. Further steps are to test the hypothesis using an experiment, to compare the measurements to the expected results, and to publish the findings.

The search results provide comprehensive information about experimental research methodology across various disciplines including psychology, political science, and the natural sciences.

message_text:
Perfect! All tasks completed successfully. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Summary

I've successfully analyzed the paper "Experimental study of inequality and unpredictability in an artificial cultural market" and extracted 8 key triples:

**Paper Classification:** `contribution` (the paper conducts an original experimental study)

**Identified Triples:**
1. **Social influence** (concept) - Used to vary the strength in the market experiment
2. **Economic inequality** (concept) - Proposed as a key outcome of social influence
3. **Predictability** (concept) - Used to examine how success becomes harder to predict
4. **Hit song** (task) - Real-world motivation for the study
5. **Music industry** (task) - Domain for the artificial market experiment
6. **Quality (business)** (concept) - Used to analyze its relationship with success
7. **Experiment** (method) - Proposed as the novel methodology with 14,341 participants
8. **Prediction market** (concept) - Related to the study's investigation of prediction difficulty

All Wikipedia URLs are verified and validated. The JSON output file has been successfully updated and passes all validation checks.

Sources:
- [Social influence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_influence)
